Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Robotic-Assisted Versus Conventional Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment. Sample size calculation assumed a 5-point difference in the Knee Society score with 99% power, requiring 628 patients per group.

Participants.evidence: 1406 patients were eligible and randomized to receive robotic-assisted TKA (700 patients, 750 knees) or conventional TKA (706 patients, 766 knees).

Intervention.evidence: randomized to receive robotic-assisted TKA (700 patients, 750 knees) or conventional TKA (706 patients, 766 knees).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the long-term efficacy of robotic-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to conventional TKA in terms of functional outcomes, radiographic parameters, survivorship, and complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Knee Society score, measured preoperatively and at a mean follow-up of 13 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 1406 patients were eligible and randomized to receive robotic-assisted TKA (700 patients, 750 knees) or conventional TKA (706 patients, 766 knees). Conducted from January 2002 to February 2008 at a single center.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At follow-up, 674 patients in each group were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were observed in Knee Society scores (robotic: 93 ± 5, conventional: 92 ± 6; p = 0.321), WOMAC scores, or UCLA activity scores.

Harms.evidence: Complications were comparable, with 2% of knees in each group experiencing superficial infections treated with antibiotics.
